Fair-by-design matching

David GarcÃ­a-Soriano â€ƒâ€ƒ Francesco Bonchi
Abstract

Matching algorithms are used routinely to match donors to recipients for solid organs transplantation, for the assignment of medical residents to hospitals, record linkage in databases, scheduling jobs on machines, network switching, online advertising, and image recognition, among others. Although many optimal solutions may exist to a given matching problem, when the elements that shall or not be included in a solution correspond to individuals, it becomes of paramount importance that the solution be selected fairly.

In this paper we study individual fairness in matching problems. Given that many maximum matchings may exist, each one satisfying a different set of individuals, the only way to guarantee fairness is through randomization. Hence we introduce the distributional maxmin fairness framework which provides, for any given input instance, the strongest guarantee possible simultaneously for all individuals in terms of satisfaction probability (the probability of being matched in the solution). Specifically, a probability distribution over feasible solutions is maxmin-fair if it is not possible to improve the satisfaction probability of any individual without decreasing it for some other individual which is no better off. In the special case of matchings in bipartite graphs, our framework is equivalent to the egalitarian mechanism of Bogomolnaia and Mouline.

Our main contribution is a polynomial-time algorithm for fair matching building on techniques from minimum cuts, and edge-coloring algorithms for regular bipartite graphs, and transversal theory. For bipartite graphs, our algorithm runs in Oâ€‹((|V|2+|E|â€‹|V|2/3)â‹…(logâ¡|V|)2)ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘‰2ğ¸superscriptğ‘‰23superscriptğ‘‰2O((|V|^{2}+|E||V|^{2/3})\cdot(\log|V|)^{2}) expected time and scales to graphs with tens of millions of vertices and hundreds of millions of edges. To the best of our knowledge, this provides the first large-scale implementation of the egalitarian mechanism. Our experimental analysis confirms that our method provides stronger satisfaction probability guarantees than non-trivial baselines.

Algorithmic bias fairness matching combinatorial optimization

1 Introduction

Decision-making tools relying on data and quantitative measures have become pervasive in application domains such as education and employment, finance, search and recommendation, policy making, and criminal justice. Awareness and concern about the risks of unfair automated decisions is quickly rising, as it has been argued that decisions informed by data analysis could have inadvertent discriminatory effects due to potential bias existing in the data or encoded in automated decisions. Several reportsÂ Obama1 ; Obama2 call for algorithms that are â€œfair by designâ€ and identify â€œpoorly designed matching systemsâ€ as one of the main flaws of algorithmic decision-making. The way to tackle the ensuing ethical and societal issues has garnered the attention of the research communityÂ DworkKeynote . However, despite the fact that matching mechanisms lie at the basis of many automated decision systems, the bulk of the research in the area of algorithmic bias and fairness has mainly focused on avoiding discrimination against a sensitive attribute (i.e., a protected social group) in supervised machine learningÂ fair_ml .

Our work departs from this literature in three main directions: (1) we focus on individual fairness (as opposed to group-level fairness); (2) we focus on bias stemming from the algorithm design itself, rather than the bias existing in the input data; (3) instead of supervised learning we focus on matching problems, where the solution may not be unique and individuals correspond to elements to be included in the solution.

In this setting, the satisfaction (utility) function of each individual is based on whether the individual has been selected or not for inclusion. At the very least, two individuals satisfying all relevant criteria equally well (e.g., having the same skill set) should have, in principle, the same expected utility; moreover, individuals having a wider or a more unique skill set (covering relevant criteria that others canâ€™t cover), should reasonably be rewarded with higher expected utility. This is often not the case as algorithms may be â€œbiased by designâ€: bias may stem from something as petty as the order in which the algorithm chooses to process the list of candidates in its main loop (e.g., by irrelevant attributes such as alphabetical order or application date), or details about the internal workings of the algorithm. The prototypical example of a â€œbiased by designâ€ algorithm (in a rather extreme way) arises in the context of stable matching (a different problem from the one considered in this paper): the Gale-Shapley algorithmÂ GaleShapley produces a solution which is always the best for every man and the worst for every woman, among all feasible solutions, despite the existence of another solution which lies provably â€œin the middleâ€ for every man and womanÂ geometry_matchings .

Algorithmic bias and randomization. Consider a job-search setting where we have a certain number of positions and applicants. Assume that each applicant has a binary fitting for each of the positions (either she is fit for the job or not) and a binary satisfaction function (either she is selected or not). This can be modeled as a matching problem in a bipartite graph. Unless a matching covering simultaneously all applicants exists, some of them will have to be left out. An unselected applicant could notice that there are other matchings (even maximum-size matchings) satisfying her. However, any deterministic algorithm is programmed to pick a specific one which may not include her: she might rightfully deem this unfair.

Unlike the Gale-Shapley algorithm, whose bias can be simply characterized by a theorem, for the problems we consider in this paper it may be hard to tell in advance which particular individuals a given algorithm favours. However, the fact that the bias is not easy to pinpoint does not mean it does not exist, just that we do not know what it is.

Since no single candidate solution satisfying all individuals at the same time can exist in general, we turn our attention to randomized algorithms, which make random choices to pick from among several valid solutions.

In our job-search example, imagine there is a single open position and nğ‘›n applicants fit for it. Intuitively, all applicants are â€œequally qualifiedâ€ in this case and the fairest solution would choose one of them uniformly at random, giving each applicant a guaranteed satisfaction (matching) probability of 1/n1ğ‘›1/n. However, as the graph between applicants and jobs grows more complex, it becomes unclear how to proceed, or what properties one should demand of a fair distribution of solutions. Our next example illustrates why requiring exactly the same satisfaction probability for all individuals would not make for a good definition.

Example 1 (Satisfaction probability).

Consider the problem of finding a matching on the bipartite graph of Figure 1 between people (on the left) and jobs (on the right). Let ğ’°={a0,a1,a2,a3}ğ’°subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘3{\mathcal{U}}=\{a_{0},a_{1},a_{2},a_{3}\} and let ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}} denote the set of all possible matchings. This artificially restricts the satisfaction probability ofÂ a0subscriptğ‘0a_{0}. The insight from ExampleÂ 1 leads us to the key definition of our work. Our aim is to provide, on any given input instance, the strongest guarantee possible for all individuals, in terms of satisfaction probability. We thus introduce the distributional maxmin fairness framework. Informally, a distribution over matchings is maxmin-fair if it is impossible to improve the satisfaction probability of any individual without decreasing it for some other individual which is no better off (see SectionÂ 2 for a formal definition).

Example 2 (Maxmin-fair distribution).

Overview of our contributions. The contributions of this paper can be summarized as follows:

  • â€¢

    We introduce and characterize the distributional maxmin-fairness framework providing, on any given problem instance, the strongest guarantee possible for all individuals, in terms of satisfaction probability (Section 2). While in this paper, for sake of simplicity of presentation, we focus on matching problems, our definition applies to a wider variety of problems (such as those listed in ExampleÂ 5).

  • â€¢

    In Section 3, we show that when the structure of valid solutions forms a matroid (which is the case for matchings), maxmin-fairness minimizes the largest inequality gap in satisfaction probabilities between all pairs of individuals, among all Pareto-efficient distributions (TheoremÂ 3.2). We also observe that for such problems the â€œprice of fairnessâ€ is zero: maxmin fairness is attainable at no cost in solution size.

  • â€¢

    We give a characterization of the â€œdegree of fairnessâ€ attainable in any bipartite matching instance (TheoremÂ A.2) and any matroid problem instance (TheoremÂ A.2), generalizing the classical marriage theorem due to HallÂ hall .

  • â€¢

    We apply our framework to matching problems in bipartite graphs (SectionsÂ 4 and 5), leading to our main contribution: an exact algorithm for maxmin-fair bipartite matching with running time Oâ€‹((|V|2+|E|â€‹|V|2/3)â‹…(logâ¡|V|)2)ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘‰2ğ¸superscriptğ‘‰23superscriptğ‘‰2O((|V|^{2}+|E||V|^{2/3})\cdot(\log|V|)^{2}) (TheoremÂ 5.1). We also obtain a polynomial time maxmin-fair algorithm for matching in general graphs by a reduction to the aforementioned bipartite case (TheoremÂ 6.3).

  • â€¢

    We discuss how to achieve full transparency for real-world deployment of our framework (Section 7). The discussion leads to the problem of producing a maxmin-fair distribution with small support, for which we offer an approach making small modifications to our algorithm.

  • â€¢

    Our experiments (SectionÂ 8) show that our algorithm performs faster in practice than its theoretical running time and scales to graphs with tens of millions of vertices and hundreds of millions of edges, taking only a few minutes on a simple architecture. Our analysis confirms that our method provides stronger satisfaction probability guarantees than non-trivial baselines.

2 Problem definition

In this section we provide the key definition of our distributional maxmin-fairness framework, considering a very general search problem instance â„=(ğ’°,ğ’®)â„ğ’°ğ’®{\mathcal{I}}=({\mathcal{U}},{\mathcal{S}}) defined over a finite set of individuals ğ’°ğ’°{\mathcal{U}} and where ğ’®â‰ âˆ…ğ’®{\mathcal{S}}\neq\emptyset denotes the set of feasible solutions for the problem instance â„â„{\mathcal{I}}. (For example, instance â„â„{\mathcal{I}} could represent a bipartite graph between jobs and a set ğ’°ğ’°{\mathcal{U}} of applicants, and ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}} the set of all matchings.) We assume that for every solution Sâˆˆğ’®ğ‘†ğ’®S\in{\mathcal{S}}, each individual uâˆˆğ’°ğ‘¢ğ’°u\in{\mathcal{U}} is either fully satisfied or fully dissatisfied, and this is the only property of the solution we are concerned with. Thus, for the sake of simplicity, we will identify each solution in ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}} with the subset of users satisfied by it, so ğ’®âŠ†2ğ’°ğ’®superscript2ğ’°{\mathcal{S}}\subseteq 2^{{\mathcal{U}}}. Note that ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}} is defined implicitly by the structure of the problem, and not explicitly encoded in the input.

Given â„â„{\mathcal{I}}, our problem is to return an element of ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}} while providing a fairness guarantee to all individuals in ğ’°ğ’°{\mathcal{U}}. Since in general no single candidate solution satisfying all uâˆˆğ’°ğ‘¢ğ’°u\in{\mathcal{U}} at the same time exists (ğ’°âˆ‰Sğ’°ğ‘†{\mathcal{U}}\notin S), we seek a randomized algorithm ğ’œğ’œ{\mathcal{A}} that, for any given problem instance â„â„{\mathcal{I}}, always halts and selects one solution ğ’œâ€‹(â„)ğ’œâ„{\mathcal{A}}({\mathcal{I}}) from ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}}. Thus ğ’œğ’œ{\mathcal{A}} induces a probability distribution Dğ·D over ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}}: PrDâ¡[S]=Prâ¡[ğ’œâ€‹(â„)=S]subscriptPrğ·ğ‘†Prğ’œâ„ğ‘†\Pr_{D}[S]=\Pr[{\mathcal{A}}({\mathcal{I}})=S] for each Sâˆˆğ’®ğ‘†ğ’®S\in{\mathcal{S}}. Based on the insight from ExampleÂ 1, we next provide the key definition of our work. Informally, a distribution over solutions is maxmin-fair if it is impossible to improve the satisfaction probability of any individual without decreasing it for some other individual which is no better off.

Definition 1 (Maxmin-fairness).
A distribution Fğ¹F over ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}} is maxmin-fair for ğ’°ğ’°{\mathcal{U}} if for all distributions Dğ·D over ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}} and all uâˆˆğ’°ğ‘¢ğ’°u\in{\mathcal{U}}, Dâ€‹[u]ğ·delimited-[]ğ‘¢\displaystyle{D}[{u}] >Fâ€‹[u]âŸ¹âˆƒvâˆˆğ’°âˆ£Dâ€‹[v]<Fâ€‹[v]â‰¤Fâ€‹[u].absentğ¹delimited-[]ğ‘¢ğ‘£conditionalğ’°ğ·delimited-[]ğ‘£ğ¹delimited-[]ğ‘£ğ¹delimited-[]ğ‘¢\displaystyle>{F}[{u}]\implies\exists v\in{\mathcal{U}}\mid{D}[{v}]<{F}[{v}]\leq{F}[{u}]. (1) Similarly, a randomized algorithm is maxmin-fair if it induces a maxmin-fair distribution.

Finding a maxmin-fair distribution involves solving a continuous optimization problem over (infinitely many) distributions over the set ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}} of valid solutions (which is commonly exponential in size). The challenge we face is thus how to design an efficient randomized algorithm inducing a maxmin-fair distribution.

Problem 1.

For a given search problem, design a randomized algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} which always terminates and such that, for each instance â„=(ğ’°,ğ’®)â„ğ’°ğ’®{\mathcal{I}}=({\mathcal{U}},{\mathcal{S}}), the distribution of ğ’œâ€‹(â„)ğ’œâ„{\mathcal{A}}({\mathcal{I}}) is maxmin-fair for ğ’°ğ’°{\mathcal{U}} over ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}}.

While our definition applies to a wider variety of search problems, in this paper, for sake of simplicity of presentation, we solve ProblemÂ 1 in the case where the search problem is a matching problem in a graph. Let us specify what the sets ğ’°ğ’°{\mathcal{U}} of users and ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}} of solutions are in this case (TableÂ 1 below summarizes the notation used throughout the paper).

Let G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E) be an unweighted simple graph. A matching in GğºG is a set of vertex-disjoint edges of GğºG. A maximum matching is a matching of largest size. The matching Mğ‘€M covers a vertex vâˆˆVğ‘£ğ‘‰v\in V if vğ‘£v is incident to some edge in Mğ‘€M. A set SâŠ†Vğ‘†ğ‘‰S\subseteq V is matchable if there is a matching of GğºG covering all of Sğ‘†S. In the fair matching problem, the input is a graph G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E) and a set ğ’°âŠ†Vğ’°ğ‘‰{\mathcal{U}}\subseteq V of users. While the results provided in Section 3 hold for fair-matching on a general graph, the algorithms developed in SectionsÂ 4 and 5 are for the interesting special case of one-sided fair bipartite matching problem, i.e., where GğºG is bipartite (with bipartition V=Lâ€‹âˆªË™â€‹Rğ‘‰ğ¿Ë™ğ‘…V=L\ \dot{\cup}\ R) and the set of users is given by ğ’°=Lğ’°ğ¿{\mathcal{U}}=L. By solving the one-sided fair bipartite matching problem, we also obtain a polynomial time maxmin-fair algorithm for matching in general graphs by means of a reduction to the bipartite case (see TheoremÂ 6.3).

3 Fairness and social inequality

In this section we present several properties of maxmin-fair distributions. These are of independent interest as they provide alternative definitions of maxmin-fairness (TheoremsÂ 3.1 andÂ 3.2) which are arguably just as natural as DefinitionÂ 1; moreover, the latter offers insights into the inequality distribution properties of maxmin-fairness. Some results are only stated here; their proofs may be found in AppendixÂ A.

3.1 Basic properties of maxmin-fair distributions

An important preliminary observation is that maxmin-fair distributions are unique as far as satisfaction probabilities go, even though several ways may exist to achieve the optimal satisfaction probabilities.

Lemma 1 ().

Let Fğ¹F and Dğ·D be two maxmin-fair distributions. Then Fâ€‹[u]=Dâ€‹[u]ğ¹delimited-[]ğ‘¢ğ·delimited-[]ğ‘¢{F}[{u}]={D}[{u}] for all uâˆˆğ’°ğ‘¢ğ’°u\in{\mathcal{U}}.

Example 3.

In ExampleÂ 2 we gave two maxmin-fair distributions, F1subscriptğ¹1F_{1} and F2subscriptğ¹2F_{2}, which are obtained by combining maximum matchings in different ways, but both satisfy F1â€‹[a0]=F2â€‹[a0]=1subscriptğ¹1delimited-[]subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ¹2delimited-[]subscriptğ‘01{F_{1}}[{a_{0}}]={F_{2}}[{a_{0}}]=1 and F1â€‹[x]=F2â€‹[x]=23subscriptğ¹1delimited-[]ğ‘¥subscriptğ¹2delimited-[]ğ‘¥23{F_{1}}[{x}]={F_{2}}[{x}]=\frac{2}{3} for xâˆˆ{a1,a2,a3}ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘3x\in\{a_{1},a_{2},a_{3}\}.

Given a distribution Dğ·D over ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}}, write Dâ†‘=(Î»1,â€¦,Î»n){D\uparrow\,}=(\lambda_{1},\ldots,\lambda_{n}) for the vector of satisfaction probabilities (Dâ€‹[u])uâˆˆğ’°subscriptğ·delimited-[]ğ‘¢ğ‘¢ğ’°(D[u])_{u\in{\mathcal{U}}} sorted in increasing order. Let â‰»succeeds\succ denote the lexicographical order of vectors: (v1,â€¦,vn)â‰»(w1,â€¦,wn)succeedssubscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¤1â€¦subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘›(v_{1},\ldots,v_{n})\succ(w_{1},\ldots,w_{n}) iff there is some index iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n] such that vj=wjsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘—v_{j}=w_{j} for all j<iğ‘—ğ‘–j<i and vi>wisubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–v_{i}>w_{i} (the relations âª°,â‰ºsucceeds-or-equalsprecedes\succeq,\prec and âª¯precedes-or-equals\preceq are defined similarly). The following holds.

Theorem 3.1 ().

A distribution Fğ¹F is maxmin-fair if and only if Fâ†‘âª°Dâ†‘{F\uparrow\,}\succeq{D\uparrow\,} for all distributions Dğ·D over ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}}.

In other words, a maxmin-fair distribution maximizes the smallest satisfaction probability; subject to that, it maximizes the second-smallest satisfaction probability, and so on.

Example 4.

In ExamplesÂ 1 and Â 2 we have F1â†‘=F2â†‘=(1,23,23,23)â‰»Dâ†‘=(23,23,23,23){F_{1}\uparrow\,}={F_{2}\uparrow\,}=(1,\frac{2}{3},\frac{2}{3},\frac{2}{3})\succ{D\uparrow\,}=(\frac{2}{3},\frac{2}{3},\frac{2}{3},\frac{2}{3}). An important observation is that a maxmin-fair distribution always exists for any search problem instance with a feasible solution:

Corollary 1.

Given a search problem instance â„=(ğ’°,ğ’®)â„ğ’°ğ’®{\mathcal{I}}=({\mathcal{U}},{\mathcal{S}}), a maxmin-fair distribution always exists.

Proof.

The probability vectors defining distributions over ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}} form a non-empty compact set, and the mapping from such vectors to their corresponding sorted satisfaction vectors is continuous, so the claim follows from Weirstrass theorem. âˆ

3.2 Matroid problems

Theorem 3.1 above provides a definition of maxmin-fairness alternative to DefinitionÂ 1. At the end of this section (TheoremÂ 3.2) we provide a second alternative definition characterizing the inequality properties of the distribution of satisfaction probabilities, i.e., the differences between the satisfaction of the least and most satisfied individuals. It turns out that for a large class of problems, this difference is minimized in a maxmin-fair distribution, making the maxmin-fair distribution the most equitable. However this does not hold in general for all search problems.

To be able to state the class of problems for which TheoremÂ 3.2 holds, we need to review the concept of matroids. Many search and optimization problems can be formulated in terms of matroids; they also provide a convenient framework to state and simplify the proofs of some of our results.

Definition 2 (Matroid problem).

Let Lğ¿L be a finite set. A matroid with ground set Lğ¿L is a non-empty collection Mğ‘€M of subsets of Lğ¿L satisfying the following two properties: (1) if AâˆˆMğ´ğ‘€A\in M and BâŠ†Ağµğ´B\subseteq A, then BâˆˆMğµğ‘€B\in M; (2) for any XâŠ†Lğ‘‹ğ¿X\subseteq L, all maximal subsets of Xğ‘‹X (with respect to set inclusion) belonging to Mğ‘€M have the same size.

A search problem is a matroid problem if for any instance â„=(ğ’°,ğ’®)â„ğ’°ğ’®{\mathcal{I}}=({\mathcal{U}},{\mathcal{S}}), the set ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}} is a matroid. The elements of a matroid Mğ‘€M are called independent sets. The maximal elements of Mğ‘€M are called bases. All bases have the same size. The rank function of Mğ‘€M is ÏMâ€‹(S)=maxâ¡{|X|âˆ£XâŠ†S,XâˆˆM}subscriptğœŒğ‘€ğ‘†conditionalğ‘‹ğ‘‹ğ‘†ğ‘‹ğ‘€\rho_{M}(S)=\max\{|X|\mid X\subseteq S,X\in M\}.

Example 5.

The following are matroids (seeÂ lawler_book ):

  • â€¢

    The collection of sets of matchable vertices in a graphÂ matching_book . This well-known result follows from a theorem of BergeÂ berge_matchings that we may extend any matchable set of vertices to a matchable set of maximum size. By contrast, the collections of sets of edges forming a matching is not a matroid.

  • â€¢

    The collection of sets of vertices in a graph for which edge-disjoint paths from another single specified vertex exist.

  • â€¢

    The collection of linearly independent sets of vectors over a finite vector space.

  • â€¢

    The collection of forests (acyclic sets of edges) in a graph.

The search problems corresponding to finding any of the above are matroid problems.

Notice that any set Xğ‘‹X appearing with non-zero probability in a maxmin-fair distribution must be maximum in size; otherwise, by property (2) in DefinitionÂ 2, Xğ‘‹X is not maximal so we could replace Xğ‘‹X with some strict superset YâŠ‹Xğ‘‹ğ‘ŒY\supsetneq X, which can only increase the satisfaction probability of every uâˆˆLğ‘¢ğ¿u\in L. It is in this sense that the â€œprice of fairnessâ€ is zero for matroid problems: the support of a maxmin-fair distribution consists only of solutions of maximum size, so it is never necessary to trade fairness for solution size. In particular this holds for matching problems as well.

3.3 Minmax-fairness

By definition, maxmin-fair distributions give the highest possible satisfaction probabilities to the worst-off individuals. To investigate the inequality properties of these, we introduce a dual notion of minmax-fair distributions, which by contrast give the lowest possible satisfaction probabilities to the best-off individuals. It turns out that for matroid problems both notions coincide, provided that we exclude Pareto-inefficient distributions.

Definition 3 (Pareto efficiency).

A distribution Eğ¸E is (ex-ante) Pareto-efficient if there is no distribution Dğ·D such that Dâ€‹[u]â‰¥Eâ€‹[u]ğ·delimited-[]ğ‘¢ğ¸delimited-[]ğ‘¢{D}[{u}]\geq{E}[{u}] for all uâˆˆğ’°ğ‘¢ğ’°u\in{\mathcal{U}} and Dâ€‹[u]>Eâ€‹[u]ğ·delimited-[]ğ‘¢ğ¸delimited-[]ğ‘¢{D}[{u}]>{E}[{u}] for at least one uâˆˆğ’°ğ‘¢ğ’°u\in{\mathcal{U}}.

The notion of Pareto-efficiency expresses the impossibility of improving the satisfaction probability of some user without detriment to anyone else. Clearly any maxmin-fair distribution is Pareto-efficient, hence any solution in its support is maximal (with regard to set inclusion).

The notion of minmax-fairness outlined above requires that no user satisfaction can be decreased without increasing that of another user which is no worse off, or losing Pareto-efficiency.

Definition 4.

A Pareto-efficient distribution Fğ¹F over ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}} is minmax-Pareto (or minmax fair) for ğ’°ğ’°{\mathcal{U}} if for all Pareto-efficient distributions Dğ·D over ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}} and all uâˆˆğ’°ğ‘¢ğ’°u\in{\mathcal{U}}, it holds that

Dâ€‹[u]ğ·delimited-[]ğ‘¢\displaystyle{D}[{u}] <Fâ€‹[u]âŸ¹âˆƒvâˆˆğ’°âˆ£Dâ€‹[v]>â€‹Fâ€‹[v]â‰¥Fâ€‹[u].inner-productğ¹delimited-[]ğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ’°ğ·delimited-[]ğ‘£ğ¹delimited-[]ğ‘£ğ¹delimited-[]ğ‘¢\displaystyle<{F}[{u}]\implies\exists v\in{\mathcal{U}}\mid{D}[{v}]>{F}[{v}]\geq{F}[{u}].

Requiring Pareto-efficiency is redundant for maxmin-fairness, but crucial for minmax-Pareto efficiency; without it, the definition would be met by a distribution of solutions satisfying nobody (for example, a solution which always returns the empty matching).

In AppendixÂ A we present analogues to LemmaÂ 1 and TheoremÂ 3.1 (LemmaÂ 1 and TheoremÂ A.1) for minmax-fairness.

3.4 Inequality properties

The main result of this section, TheoremÂ 3.2 is that, for matroid problems, the notions of minmax fairness and maxmin fairness coincide; intuitively, any excess satisfaction probability for the best-off user can be taken away from him and redistributed to others. This also implies that the maxmin-fair solution minimizes the largest gap in satisfaction probabilities; among those, it minimizes the second-largest gap, etc.

Definition 5.

The sorted inequality vector of a distribution Dğ·D over ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}}, written Dâ‰ â†“superscriptsubscriptğ·â†“{D}_{\neq}^{\downarrow}, is the vector of all pairwise differences in the satisfaction probabilities of the elements of ğ’°ğ’°{\mathcal{U}} under Dğ·D, sorted in decreasing order.

Theorem 3.2 ().

For matroid problems, the following are equivalent: (1) Dğ·D is maxmin-fair; (2) Dğ·D is minmax-Pareto; (3) Dğ·D is Pareto-efficient and Dâ‰ â†“âª¯Eâ‰ â†“precedes-or-equalssuperscriptsubscriptğ·â†“superscriptsubscriptğ¸â†“{D}_{\neq}^{\downarrow}\preceq{E}_{\neq}^{\downarrow} for all Pareto-efficient distributions Eğ¸E over ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}}.

The proof may be found in AppendixÂ A.

Note that this result does not hold in general for non-matroid problems; the following shows a counterexample.

Example 6.

Consider the problem instance where the set of individuals is ğ’°={0,1,2,3}ğ’°0123{\mathcal{U}}=\{0,1,2,3\} and the set of feasible solutions is ğ’®={{0,1},{1,3},{0,2,3}}ğ’®0113023{\mathcal{S}}=\{\{0,1\},\{1,3\},\{0,2,3\}\}. Here elements 111 and 222 never appear together in a solution, so the minimum satisfaction probability cannot exceed 1212\frac{1}{2}. In order to achieve 1212\frac{1}{2} we need to choose {0,2,3}023\{0,2,3\} with probability exactly 1212\frac{1}{2}; this fixes the satisfaction probabilities of 222 and 111 to 1212\frac{1}{2}, and to maximize the second-smallest probability we need to pick {0,1}01\{0,1\} and {1,3}13\{1,3\} with probability 1414\frac{1}{4} each. This is the maxmin-fair distribution D1subscriptğ·1D_{1} and its maximum inequality is 1414\frac{1}{4}. However, a similar argument shows that the minmax-fair distribution D2subscriptğ·2D_{2} is different: it uses each element of ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}} with probability 1313\frac{1}{3} and has maximum inequality 1313\frac{1}{3}.

Note that in this case one may verify that D1subscriptğ·1D_{1} still minimizes maximum inequality, but by considering the complements of each element of ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}}, one can give a similar example where the maxmin-fair distribution does not minimize inequality.

4 A polynomial-time algorithm for maxmin-fair matching

In this section we present our main contribution: a polynomial-time algorithm for maxmin-fair matching. We present our algorithm for the one-sided fair bipartite matching problem. This is the special case of fair matching where:

  • â€¢

    GğºG is bipartite (with bipartition V=Lâ€‹âˆªË™â€‹Rğ‘‰ğ¿Ë™ğ‘…V=L\ \dot{\cup}\ R),

  • â€¢

    the set of users is ğ’°=Lğ’°ğ¿{\mathcal{U}}=L,

  • â€¢

    there is a maximum matching covers all the right-side vertices but not all the left-side vertices (i.e., Ïâ€‹(L)=|R|<|L|ğœŒğ¿ğ‘…ğ¿\rho(L)=|R|<|L|),

  • â€¢

    there are no degree-0 vertices (which can always be removed).

This setting corresponds to the job-search setting that we use in our examples throughout the paper. We will see later (SectionÂ 5.2) that the general fair matching problem in non-bipartite graphs, with arbitrary user sets ğ’°âŠ†Vğ’°ğ‘‰{\mathcal{U}}\subseteq V and with no further restrictions, can be reduced to this special case in polynomial time. Before presenting the building blocks of our algorithm in full detail, we provide an overview of our techniques. Some results are only stated here; their proofs may be found in AppendixÂ B.

4.1 Overview of our techniques

We next provide an overview of how we obtain our main result: an efficient algorithm for maxmin-fair bipartite matching.

  1. (1)

    The first ingredient (Section 4.2) is a characterization of the fairness parameter, i.e., the maximum satisfaction probability which can be guaranteed for every user. By using Hallâ€™s theorem we prove (CorollaryÂ 2) that the fairness parameter is determined by a â€œblockingâ€ set of vertices with the smallest neighborhood-to-size ratio. Unfortunately, the proof does not lead to an efficient algorithm to find this set.

  2. (2)

    Thus we proceed to write down a linear program for a fractional variant of the problem (Section 4.3). Inspired by a technique developed by CharikarÂ charikar for the densest-subgraph problem, we show (LemmaÂ 3) that any fractional solution can be leveraged to find a blocking set of vertices. The neighbors of the blocking set cannot be matched to any vertex outside the blocking set in any maxmin-fair distribution. We use this fact to argue inductively (TheoremÂ 4.3) the existence of a â€œfair decompositionâ€ of the set of left vertices with the following property: vertices on higher levels can be allowed larger satisfaction probabilities, regardless of which edges are used to match the vertices on lower levels.

  3. (3)

    Having computed the assignment probabilities xuâ€‹vsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¢ğ‘£x_{uv} (the probability of each pair of vertices being matched) of some maxmin-fair distribution within each block in the decomposition, we can turn each of them into an actual distribution of matchings by finding the Birkhoff-von Neumann decomposition of a doubly-stochastic matrix. Then we combine them into a single distribution.

  4. (4)

    To obtain our faster algorithm (which also returns the exact optimal solution), we avoid the use of linear programming and instead present a technique to find several blocks in parallel with a single min-cut computation (SectionÂ 5). We show that a logarithmic number of minimum cut computations suffice to obtain the fair decomposition in full. Then we argue that given the decomposition and satisfaction probabilities, the required distribution of matchings can be found by coloring the edges of an appropriately constructed regular bipartite graph, for which task we leverage the fast algorithm of Goel et al.Â perfect_nlogn .

In the one-sided fair bipartite matching problem, the fairness parameter Ï€â€‹(G)ğœ‹ğº\pi(G) is equal to the optimum value of the LP inÂ (3).

4.4 Fair decompositions

The next ingredient towards an efficient algorithm is to find a decomposition of Lğ¿L according to different levels of satisfaction probability in the maxmin-fair distribution. In FigureÂ 2, the set of left vertices with smallest neighbor-to-size ratio is the set B1={a5,a4}subscriptğµ1subscriptğ‘5subscriptğ‘4B_{1}=\{a_{5},a_{4}\}, with Î“â€‹(B1)={b3}Î“subscriptğµ1subscriptğ‘3\Gamma(B_{1})=\{b_{3}\}. By CorollaryÂ 2, the fairness parameter of the graph in the picture is 1212\frac{1}{2}. But in order to actually match a5subscriptğ‘5a_{5} and a4subscriptğ‘4a_{4} with probability 1212\frac{1}{2}, b3subscriptğ‘3b_{3} must be matched to one of the two every single time. Hence the edge (a3,b3)subscriptğ‘3subscriptğ‘3(a_{3},b_{3}) can never be used to in a maxmin-maxmin-fair solution. After removing B1subscriptğµ1B_{1} and Î“â€‹(B1)Î“subscriptğµ1\Gamma(B_{1}) from the graph, the next set of left vertices with smallest neighbor-to-size ratio is the set B2={a1,a2,a3}subscriptğµ2subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘3B_{2}=\{a_{1},a_{2},a_{3}\} and again we find that edge (a0,b1)subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1(a_{0},b_{1}) cannot be used. The last set we find in this way is B3={a0}subscriptğµ3subscriptğ‘0B_{3}=\{a_{0}\}.

We refer to B1,B2,B3subscriptğµ1subscriptğµ2subscriptğµ3B_{1},B_{2},B_{3} as the blocks of the fair decomposition; and to the increasing sequence of sets S1=B1,S2=B1âˆªB2formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘†1subscriptğµ1subscriptğ‘†2subscriptğµ1subscriptğµ2S_{1}=B_{1},S_{2}=B_{1}\cup B_{2} and S3=B1âˆªB2âˆªB3subscriptğ‘†3subscriptğµ1subscriptğµ2subscriptğµ3S_{3}=B_{1}\cup B_{2}\cup B_{3} as the fairly isolated sets. This motivates the following definitions.

For AâŠ†Lğ´ğ¿A\subseteq L, denote by G|A|ğºğ´G{{\mathbin{|}}\raise-3.87495pt\hbox{${\scriptstyle{A}}$}} the subgraph of GğºG induced by AâˆªÎ“â€‹(A)ğ´Î“ğ´A\cup\Gamma(A), and by G/Ağºğ´G/A the subgraph of GğºG induced by (LâˆªR)âˆ–(AâˆªÎ“â€‹(A))ğ¿ğ‘…ğ´Î“ğ´(L\cup R)\setminus(A\cup\Gamma(A)). For any subgraph Hğ»H of GğºG, let Ï€â€‹(H)ğœ‹ğ»\pi(H) (resp., Î â€‹(H)Î ğ»\Pi(H)) be the minimum (resp., maximum) satisfaction probability of an element of Vâ€‹(H)âˆ©Lğ‘‰ğ»ğ¿V(H)\cap L in a maxmin-fair distribution. The nonempty set XâŠ†Lğ‘‹ğ¿X\subseteq L is fairly isolated if Î â€‹(G|X)<Ï€â€‹(G/X)Î |ğºğ‘‹ğœ‹ğºğ‘‹\Pi(G{{\mathbin{|}}\raise-3.87495pt\hbox{${\scriptstyle{X}}$}})<\pi(G/X) or X=Lğ‘‹ğ¿X=L. Finding fairly isolated sets enables a â€œdivide and conquerâ€ strategy to find maxmin-fair distributions, since it turns out that matchings used inside Xğ‘‹X have no bearing on the satisfactions needed for users in Lâˆ–Xğ¿ğ‘‹L\setminus X. 4.5 Description of the basic algorithm

TheoremÂ 4.3 and LemmaÂ 3 suggest a line of attack to solve the one-sided fair bipartite matching problem, outlined in AlgorithmÂ 1 below. First, find the blocks B1,â€¦,Bksubscriptğµ1â€¦subscriptğµğ‘˜B_{1},\ldots,B_{k} in a fair decomposition. Second, find a maxmin-fair distribution111Each of these distributions can be represented by a list of pairs (pâ€‹râ€‹oâ€‹bâ€‹aâ€‹bâ€‹iâ€‹lâ€‹iâ€‹tâ€‹y,mâ€‹aâ€‹tâ€‹câ€‹hâ€‹iâ€‹nâ€‹g)ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘¦ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘â„ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘”(probability,matching), with the probabilities being non-negative and summing up to 1. For our second algorithm a simpler representation is possible: the distribution of matchings Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i} within each block (but not for the whole graph) is uniform over some small multiset of matchings. Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i} for each block Bisubscriptğµğ‘–B_{i}, using only edges that do not â€œcross to neighbors of lower blocksâ€ (i.e., no edge is allowed from uâˆˆBiğ‘¢subscriptğµğ‘–u\in B_{i} to vâˆˆÎ“â€‹(Bj)ğ‘£Î“subscriptğµğ‘—v\in\Gamma(B_{j}) where j<iğ‘—ğ‘–j<i). Finally, combine the distributions into a single maxmin-fair distribution Dğ·D, and draw a matching from it. Both our algorithms follow this general outline; they differ in how to perform steps 1 and 2. (We will discuss later (SectionÂ 7) an alternative implementation of step 3 which leads to distributions over a smaller number of matchings.)

Next we give the details of our first algorithm (AlgorithmÂ 2).

Step 1: Finding a fair decomposition. We will find the blocks in a bottom-up manner. To find the first block, observe the following:

Lemma 4.

The maximal set minimizing |Î“â€‹(X)|/|X|Î“ğ‘‹ğ‘‹|\Gamma(X)|/|X| is the union of all non-empty sets Xğ‘‹X minimizing |Î“â€‹(X)|/|X|Î“ğ‘‹ğ‘‹|\Gamma(X)|/|X|.

Proof.

It suffices to show that if X,Yğ‘‹ğ‘ŒX,Y are non-empty sets minimizing |Î“â€‹(X)|/|X|Î“ğ‘‹ğ‘‹|\Gamma(X)|/|X|, then XâˆªYğ‘‹ğ‘ŒX\cup Y also minimizes |Î“â€‹(X)|/|X|Î“ğ‘‹ğ‘‹|\Gamma(X)|/|X|. Indeed, suppose |Î“â€‹(Y)||Y|=|Î“â€‹(X)||X|â‰œÎ»Î“ğ‘Œğ‘ŒÎ“ğ‘‹ğ‘‹â‰œğœ†\frac{|\Gamma(Y)|}{|Y|}=\frac{|\Gamma(X)|}{|X|}\triangleq\lambda. By the submodularity of the cardinality of the neighborhood function of a graph,

|Î“â€‹(XâˆªY)|+|Î“â€‹(Xâˆ©Y)|â‰¤|Î“â€‹(X)|+|Î“â€‹(Y)|=Î»â€‹(|X|+|Y|).Î“ğ‘‹ğ‘ŒÎ“ğ‘‹ğ‘ŒÎ“ğ‘‹Î“ğ‘Œğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ|\Gamma(X\cup Y)|+|\Gamma(X\cap Y)|\leq|\Gamma(X)|+|\Gamma(Y)|=\lambda(|X|+|Y|).

Notice that |Î“â€‹(XâˆªY)|â‰¥Î»â€‹|XâˆªY|Î“ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ|\Gamma(X\cup Y)|\geq\lambda|X\cup Y| and |Î“â€‹(Xâˆ©Y)|â‰¥Î»â€‹|Xâˆ©Y|Î“ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ|\Gamma(X\cap Y)|\geq\lambda|X\cap Y| by definition. If any of these two inequalities were strict we would have the contradiction

|Î“â€‹(XâˆªY)|+|Î“â€‹(Xâˆ©Y)|>Î»â€‹(|XâˆªY|+|Xâˆ©Y|)=Î»â€‹(|X|+|Y|).Î“ğ‘‹ğ‘ŒÎ“ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘‹ğ‘Œğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ|\Gamma(X\cup Y)|+|\Gamma(X\cap Y)|>\lambda(|X\cup Y|+|X\cap Y|)=\lambda(|X|+|Y|).

Hence the inequalities are not strict, and |Î“â€‹(XâˆªY)|=Î»â€‹|XâˆªY|Î“ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ|\Gamma(X\cup Y)|=\lambda|X\cup Y|. âˆ

Along with TheoremÂ 4.3, this observation suggests the following method, described in the FindBlocks method of AlgorithmÂ 2. By solving the LP inÂ (3) and using LemmaÂ 3, we obtain a set Xğ‘‹X minimizing |Î“â€‹(S)|/|S|Î“ğ‘†ğ‘†|\Gamma(S)|/|S|. Remove Xğ‘‹X from the graph GğºG and repeat (if GğºG is non-empty); let Yğ‘ŒY be the new set obtained. If Î“â€‹(Y)/|Y|=Î“â€‹(X)/|X|Î“ğ‘Œğ‘ŒÎ“ğ‘‹ğ‘‹\Gamma(Y)/|Y|=\Gamma(X)/|X|, then replace Xğ‘‹X with Xâ€²=XâˆªYsuperscriptğ‘‹â€²ğ‘‹ğ‘ŒX^{\prime}=X\cup Y and repeat the process of finding a minimizer Yğ‘ŒY via LPÂ (3); this strictly increases the size of Xğ‘‹X. Eventually we will obtain a Yğ‘ŒY satisfying |Î“â€‹(Y)|/|Y|>Î“â€‹(X)/|X|Î“ğ‘Œğ‘ŒÎ“ğ‘‹ğ‘‹|\Gamma(Y)|/|Y|>\Gamma(X)/|X|, at which point we know that Xğ‘‹X is the maximal set minimizing Î“â€‹(S)/|S|Î“ğ‘†ğ‘†\Gamma(S)/|S|, i.e., the first non-trivial block B1subscriptğµ1B_{1} is Xğ‘‹X. Now remove B1subscriptğµ1B_{1} and Î“â€‹(B1)Î“subscriptğµ1\Gamma(B_{1}) from GğºG and repeat (if applicable) to obtain B2,â€¦,Bksubscriptğµ2â€¦subscriptğµğ‘˜B_{2},\ldots,B_{k}.

Step 2: Obtaining a fair distribution for each block. The idea of this step is first to calculate the assignment probabilities xuâ€‹vsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¢ğ‘£x_{uv} for all uâˆˆL,vâˆˆRformulae-sequenceğ‘¢ğ¿ğ‘£ğ‘…u\in L,v\in R, i.e., the probability that uğ‘¢u is matched to vğ‘£v in some fixed maxmin-fair distribution Fğ¹F. As of yet these probabilities are unknown (and, unlike satisfaction probabilities, they need not be the same for all maxmin-fair distributions). However, we do know some conditions that they must satisfy because we know (from TheoremÂ 4.3) the satisfaction probabilities of the left vertices in Fğ¹F, and all the right vertices need to be matched with probability 1 under our assumption that Ïâ€‹(L)=|R|ğœŒğ¿ğ‘…\rho(L)=|R|. These conditions may be expressed as linear constraints in xuâ€‹vsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¢ğ‘£x_{uv}, so we will find suitable values for xuâ€‹vsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¢ğ‘£x_{uv} via a linear program. Finally we can turn these values into an actual distribution of matchings via the Birkhoff-von Neumann decomposition. Details follow.

By the following consequence of Birkhoff-von Neumann theorem on doubly stochastic matricesÂ birkhoff the quantities xuâ€‹vsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¢ğ‘£x_{uv} thus obtained represent the edge saturation probabilities of an actual distribution of matchings inÂ Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}:

Step 3: Combining the distributions. The last step requires combining the distributions D1,â€¦,Dksubscriptğ·1â€¦subscriptğ·ğ‘˜D_{1},\ldots,D_{k}, each defined for a block Bisubscriptğµğ‘–B_{i}, into a single maxmin-fair distribution for GğºG. The simplest way is to draw (M1,â€¦,Mk)subscriptğ‘€1â€¦subscriptğ‘€ğ‘˜(M_{1},\ldots,M_{k}) from the product distribution D1Ã—D2â€‹â€¦Ã—Dksubscriptğ·1subscriptğ·2â€¦subscriptğ·ğ‘˜D_{1}\times D_{2}\ldots\times D_{k} and return M1âˆªM2â€‹â€¦âˆªMksubscriptğ‘€1subscriptğ‘€2â€¦subscriptğ‘€ğ‘˜M_{1}\cup M_{2}\ldots\cup M_{k}. (This is an easily samplable maxmin-fair distribution with potentially large support.)

Putting all together, we obtain the following.

Theorem 4.4.

AlgorithmÂ 2 is a polynomial-time algorithm for the one-sided maxmin-fair matching problem.

5 A more efficient algorithm

The algorithm from SectionÂ 4 requires solving polynomially many LP subproblems. It was presented to showcase the main steps required, to introduce the fair decompositions, and to establish the existence of a polynomial-time algorithm. In this section we analyze a more efficient algorithm. It also follows each of the three steps outlined in AlgorithmÂ 1, but differs from AlgorithmÂ 2 in two key respects:

  • â€¢

    For step 1, it finds fairly separated sets in arbitrary order, rather than bottom-up. These sets can be found by maximum flow computations in a certain graph, and a single flow computation can be used to find many new blocks in the decomposition simultaneously.

  • â€¢

    For step 2, it uses a fast edge-coloring algorithm on a carefully constructed regular bipartite graph, allowing us to bypass the (comparatively slow) Birkhoff-von Neumann decomposition (for which the best known algorithm fromÂ perfect_nlogn runs in Ï‰â€‹(|V|â€‹|E|)ğœ”ğ‘‰ğ¸\omega(|V||E|) time).

We present pseudocode for the improved algorithm (AlgorithmÂ 3) at the end of this section. We establish the following:

Theorem 5.1 ().

AlgorithmÂ 3 solves the maxmin-fair one-sided bipartite matching problem in Oâ€‹((|V|2+|E|â€‹|V|2/3)â‹…(logâ¡|V|)2)ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘‰2ğ¸superscriptğ‘‰23superscriptğ‘‰2O((|V|^{2}+|E||V|^{2/3})\cdot(\log|V|)^{2}) expected time.

The uniform distribution over them is thus maxmin-fair for GğºG.

Now consider the case that the decomposition of GğºG has several blocks B1,â€¦,Bksubscriptğµ1â€¦subscriptğµğ‘˜B_{1},\ldots,B_{k}. The values xuâ€‹visuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘–x_{uv}^{i} for all blocks iğ‘–i can be computed from a single maximum-flow computation in Gâ€‹(Î»1,â€¦,Î»k;B1,â€¦,Bk)ğºsubscriptğœ†1â€¦subscriptğœ†ğ‘˜subscriptğµ1â€¦subscriptğµğ‘˜G(\lambda_{1},\ldots,\lambda_{k};B_{1},\ldots,B_{k}) if we know the blocks and each satisfaction probability Î»isubscriptğœ†ğ‘–\lambda_{i}. Then each corresponding coloring can be found in time Oâ€‹(ni2â€‹log2â¡(ni))ğ‘‚superscriptsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–2superscript2subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–O(n_{i}^{2}\log^{2}(n_{i})); summing these running times and noticing that âˆ‘ini2â‰¤|L|2subscriptğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–2superscriptğ¿2\sum_{i}n_{i}^{2}\leq|L|^{2}, we deduce:

Theorem 5.3.

Given the fair decomposition, a maxmin-fair distribution for all blocks in it can be found in Oâ€‹(|V|2â‹…(logâ¡|V|)2)ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘‰2superscriptğ‘‰2O(|V|^{2}\cdot(\log|V|)^{2}) expected time and Oâ€‹(|V|â€‹|E|â€‹logâ¡|V|)ğ‘‚ğ‘‰ğ¸ğ‘‰O(|V||E|\log|V|) deterministic time after a max-flow computation.

Putting all together yields TheoremÂ 5.1.

6 Generalization to non-bipartite graphs

Recall that so far we have concerned ourselves with the one-sided fair bipartite matching problem, i.e., the special case of fair matching where GğºG is bipartite (with bipartition V=Lâ€‹âˆªË™â€‹Rğ‘‰ğ¿Ë™ğ‘…V=L\ \dot{\cup}\ R) and the set of users is ğ’°=Lğ’°ğ¿{\mathcal{U}}=L.

Notably, this special case can encode any other matching problem, and moreover we can make the simplifying assumption that Lğ¿L is matchable and larger than Rğ‘…R. To show this, we make use of the following result from transversal theory.

Theorem 6.1 (Ford and FulkersonÂ transversals ).

For any graph GğºG there exists a bipartite graph Hğ»H with bipartition (LH,RH)subscriptğ¿ğ»subscriptğ‘…ğ»(L_{H},R_{H}) such that LH=Vâ€‹(G)subscriptğ¿ğ»ğ‘‰ğºL_{H}=V(G) and the collection of matchable subsets of Vâ€‹(G)ğ‘‰ğºV(G) in GğºG equals the collection of matchable subsets of LHsubscriptğ¿ğ»L_{H} in Hğ»H.

This is normally stated as â€œany matching matroid is transversalâ€. The construction of Hğ»H in TheoremÂ 6.1 can be carried out in polynomial time (seeÂ transversals_short for a simple proof). Hence the case of non-bipartite GğºG can be reduced to the one-sided bipartite case. A similar remark applies to general user sets ğ’°âŠ†Vğ’°ğ‘‰{\mathcal{U}}\subseteq V, as we can remove from LHsubscriptğ¿ğ»L_{H} the elements of Vâˆ–ğ’°ğ‘‰ğ’°V\setminus{\mathcal{U}}, which has no effect on the collection of matchable subsets of ğ’°ğ’°{\mathcal{U}} in Hğ»H.

We make the additional simplifying assumption that Rğ‘…R is matchable. If not, find an arbitrary maximum matching of GğºG and remove from Rğ‘…R all unmatched vertices. Let Râ€²superscriptğ‘…â€²R^{\prime} denote the remaining vertices.

Theorem 6.2 (Mendelsohn and DulmageÂ mendelson_dulmage ).

If both AâŠ†Lğ´ğ¿A\subseteq L and BâŠ†Rğµğ‘…B\subseteq R are matchable in a bipartite graph GğºG with bipartition (L,R)ğ¿ğ‘…(L,R), then AâˆªBğ´ğµA\cup B is also matchable in GğºG.

It follows that for each distribution of matchings of GğºG there is another distribution with the same coverage (satisfaction) probabilities for Lğ¿L and covering only elements of LâˆªRâ€²ğ¿superscriptğ‘…â€²L\cup R^{\prime}. Note that the coverage probability of each vâˆˆRâ€²ğ‘£superscriptğ‘…â€²v\in R^{\prime} in this distribution is 1. The case where Ïâ€‹(L)=|R|ğœŒğ¿ğ‘…\rho(L)=|R| is easily handled separately (any maximum matching algorithm is maxmin-fair in this case), yielding the following (see AppendixÂ B for details):

Theorem 6.3 ().

The fair matching problem on arbitrary graphs with arbitrary user sets ğ’°âŠ†Vğ’°ğ‘‰{\mathcal{U}}\subseteq V can be reduced in polynomial time to the one-sided fair bipartite matching problem on graphs where Ïâ€‹(L)=|R|<|L|ğœŒğ¿ğ‘…ğ¿\rho(L)=|R|<|L|.

Proof.

Let ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} be a maxmin-fair algorithm for one-sided bipartite matching problem described. Given a graph GğºG and a user set ğ’°ğ’°{\mathcal{U}}, we

  1. (1)

    construct Hğ»H as in TheoremÂ 6.1;

  2. (2)

    remove from LHsubscriptğ¿ğ»L_{H} the elements of Vâ€‹(G)âˆ–ğ’°ğ‘‰ğºğ’°V(G)\setminus{\mathcal{U}};

  3. (3)

    find an arbitrary maximum matching Mğ‘€M and remove from RHsubscriptğ‘…ğ»R_{H} the elements not covered by Mğ‘€M, using any polynomial-time maximum matching algorithm.

  4. (4)

    find a fair one-sided bipartite matching by either (a) using ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} on the resulting graph if |M|<|LH|ğ‘€subscriptğ¿ğ»|M|<|L_{H}| or (b) returning Mğ‘€M if |M|=|LH|ğ‘€subscriptğ¿ğ»|M|=|L_{H}|;

  5. (5)

    given the solution Sğ‘†S found at the previous step, return a matching in GğºG covering the same vertices as Sğ‘†S using an explicit algorithm for Bergeâ€™s theoremÂ edmonds_algo .

(Step (5) is technically redundant as we identify solutions with sets of matchable users, but is included for clarity.)

It is plain to see that the resulting distribution is maxmin-fair for the general problem if and only if ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} is maxmin-fair for the one-sided problem. All steps run in polynomial time, possibly excluding the call to ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} itself. âˆ

Combining TheoremsÂ 5.1 andÂ 6.3, we obtain the following.

Theorem 6.4.

The maxmin-fair matching problem on general unweighted graphs is solvable in polynomial time.

7 On transparency and practical deployment

Even a provably fair algorithm might still be perceived by the average user as a blackbox outputting an arbitrary solution. For the sake of transparency and accountability, it can be interesting to publish all the solutions in a maxmin-fair distribution (along with their respective probabilities). Once a complete fair distribution is published, convincing any user uğ‘¢u of fair treatment amounts to:

  1. (1)

    letting uğ‘¢u verify independently the fairness guarantees of the distribution (for this it is also possible to output a short certificate, based on the fair decomposition, of the fact that no higher probability for uğ‘¢u is possible in a maxmin-fair distribution); and

  2. (2)

    picking one of the published solutions at random, via any fair and transparent lottery mechanism or coin-tossing protocol (this is the only stage where randomness plays a role, as the distribution of matchings itself can be found deterministically).

One difficulty is the potentially large support size of the maxmin-fair distribution, which could prevent publication. An interesting question is if we can produce a maxmin-fair distribution with small support. It turns out that for matchings, |L|âˆ’1ğ¿1|L|-1 solutions always suffice; although the actual number can be substantially smaller in practice (as shown in SectionÂ 8).

Let us discuss how to modify our algorithm so as to find a maxmin-fair distribution Fğ¹F using at most |L|+1âˆ’kğ¿1ğ‘˜|L|+1-k matchings, where kğ‘˜k is the number of non-trivial blocks in TheoremÂ 4.3. (This could replace step 3 of AlgorithmÂ 1.) When k=1ğ‘˜1k=1, the technique from step 2 of AlgorithmÂ 3 gives a multiset of lâ‰¤|L|ğ‘™ğ¿l\leq|L| matchings.

Consider the case k=2ğ‘˜2k=2, which implies our claim for larger kğ‘˜k by induction. Suppose Dğ·D (resp., Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}) chooses matching Mi,iâˆˆ[r]subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘ŸM_{i},i\in[r] on B1subscriptğµ1B_{1} (resp., Nj,jâˆˆ[t]subscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘¡N_{j},j\in[t] on B2subscriptğµ2B_{2}) with probability pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i} (resp., qjsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—q_{j}). (Here B1âˆ©B2=âˆ…subscriptğµ1subscriptğµ2B_{1}\cap B_{2}=\emptyset.) A simple greedy algorithm can construct a distribution Zğ‘Z of matchings in B1âˆªB2subscriptğµ1subscriptğµ2B_{1}\cup B_{2} such that Dâ€‹[u]=Zâ€‹[u]ğ·delimited-[]ğ‘¢ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘¢{D}[{u}]={Z}[{u}] for uâˆˆB1ğ‘¢subscriptğµ1u\in B_{1} and Dâ€²â€‹[u]=Zâ€‹[u]superscriptğ·â€²delimited-[]ğ‘¢ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘¢{D^{\prime}}[{u}]={Z}[{u}] for uâˆˆB2ğ‘¢subscriptğµ2u\in B_{2} with at most r+tâˆ’1ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡1r+t-1 matchings, as follows.

Keep indices iâˆˆ[r]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘Ÿi\in[r], jâˆˆ[t]ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘¡j\in[t] and let Sğ‘†S denote a set of (probability, matching) pairs, which will define the desired distribution at the end. At the outset S=âˆ…ğ‘†S=\emptyset and i=j=1ğ‘–ğ‘—1i=j=1; at each iteration we add to Sğ‘†S the new pair (Î´,MiâˆªNj)ğ›¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—(\delta,M_{i}\cup N_{j}) where Î´=minâ¡(pi,qj)ğ›¿subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\delta=\min(p_{i},q_{j}). We decrement pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i} and qjsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—q_{j} by Î´ğ›¿\delta and increment iğ‘–i (resp., jğ‘—j) if pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i} (resp, qjsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—q_{j}) vanishes. The process terminates when iğ‘–i and jğ‘—j reach the end of their range, at which point |S|=r+tâˆ’1ğ‘†ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡1|S|=r+t-1 and all probabilities in Sğ‘†S sum up to 1.

We note, however, that this procedure may produce some matchings with very small probabilities, so the precision needed to specify a maxmin-fair distribution exactly will grow.

8 Experimental evaluation

We evaluate the practical performance of our fair matching algorithm by measuring its running time and its ability to scale to large graphs, and analyzing the distribution of maxmin-fair satisfaction probabilities and how they compare with those from two baselines. We also describe the features of the fair decompositions obtained.

Reproducibility. Our code is available at https://github.com/elhipercubo/maxmin_fair_bipartite_matching.git. It implements the improved algorithm from Sec.Â 5, with some implementation choices described below. It was compiled with g++ using -O3 optimizations and run on a dual-core Intel i7-7560U CPU (2.40 GHz) with 16Gb RAM.

Datasets. We used publicly-available bipartite graphs of various types, sizes and domains: all the graphs are already bipartite at the source repository, so that no preprocessing was needed. TableÂ 2 reports their main characteristics.

Methods tested. We compare the following four methods to output maximum matchings:

(UF)

Unfair: A standard maximum matching algorithm using maximum flows, optimized for runtime using the techniques fromÂ hipr . We use it for runtime comparisons only, because such a deterministic mechanism is inherently unfair as argued in SectionÂ 1.

(MF)

Maxmin fair: Our mechanism, using the improved algorithm from Sec.Â 5.

(PS)

Probabilistic Serial (fromÂ pserial ): The goal here is to find a set of edge flows from Lğ¿L to Rğ‘…R which can be converted into a matching distribution by using the Birkhoff-von Neumann decomposition.

PS attempts to find a fair flow via a greedy algorithm, as follows: each user uâˆˆLğ‘¢ğ¿u\in L sends flow at the same fixed rate, sharing this rate equally among her neighbours. When the outgoing flow of uâˆˆLğ‘¢ğ¿u\in L (or the ingoing flow of vâˆˆRğ‘£ğ‘…v\in R) reaches 1, remove uğ‘¢u (or vğ‘£v). Repeat while there are edges remaining.

UnlikeÂ MF, this mechanism is not Pareto-efficient (i.e., it does not necessarily return maximum matchings), but likeÂ MF, a single run of the mechanism can be used to output all satisfaction probabilities.

(RP)

Random Priority (seeÂ pserial ): It finds a matchable set of vertices as follows:

Let S=âˆ…ğ‘†S=\emptyset. Process all users in random order, adding user uğ‘¢u to Sğ‘†S if Sâˆª{u}ğ‘†ğ‘¢S\cup\{u\} is matchable. Return a matching covering the final set Sğ‘†S.

LikeÂ MF, this mechanism is Pareto-efficient, but unlikeÂ MF, a single run of the mechanism only outputs a single matching and hence cannot be used to compute all satisfaction probabilities.

The latter two methods arose from work in economics in a different setting: randomized assignments on full bipartite graphs with ordinal preferences, i.e., where every uâˆˆLğ‘¢ğ¿u\in L has a full ranking of all possible partners vâˆˆRğ‘£ğ‘…v\in R, and the goal is to design mechanisms which are ordinally efficient. (By contrast, in our setting the graph is not complete but there are no ordinal preferences: each user considers all of its neighbours equally desirable.) However they can be naturally applied in our context as well.

Implementation. We used the improved algorithm from Sec.Â 5. For max flow computations we chose the highest-label push-relabel algorithm ofÂ push_relabel , which performs best with the gap heuristic fromÂ eff_pushrelabel . We follow Goldberg techniques fromÂ hipr : efficient gap detection is done via bucket lists of active nodes at each levelÂ hipr , and we arrange edges from/to the same vertex consecutively to take advantage of cache locality. We avoid floating-point computations by using exact integral multipliers.

For reasons of simplicity and/or practical efficiency, our implementation departs from the pseudocode in AlgorithmÂ 3 in the points below. None of these changes affect correctness.

  • â€¢

    In FairDecomposition (line 8), only a pre-flow algorithm (the first phase ofÂ push_relabel ) is run. This always suffices to find min-cuts (not max-flows) and thus fairly separated sets, and can halve the runtime.

  • â€¢

    In FairDecomposition (line 7), instead of setting Î»iâ€²=(Î»i+Î¼i)/2superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–â€²subscriptğœ†ğ‘–subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–2\lambda_{i}^{\prime}=(\lambda_{i}+\mu_{i})/2 when building the graph Gâ€‹(Î»1â€²,â€¦,Î»tâ€²;T1,â€¦,Tt)ğºsuperscriptsubscriptğœ†1â€²â€¦superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘¡â€²subscriptğ‘‡1â€¦subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘¡G(\lambda_{1}^{\prime},\ldots,\lambda_{t}^{\prime};T_{1},\ldots,T_{t}), we set it to |Î“â€‹(Ti)|/|Ti|Î“subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–|\Gamma(T_{i})|/|T_{i}|. That is, our implementation guesses optimistically that Tisubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–T_{i} is actually a single block in the decomposition, with the pre flow computation used to verify that guess or split the block in two. This also allows us to change the terminating condition (line 6) and stop earlier: rather than stopping when Î»isubscriptğœ†ğ‘–\lambda_{i} and Î¼isubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–\mu_{i} are very close, which may occur long after the full decomposition have been found, we stop when no block is split. This new choice for Î»iâ€²superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–â€²\lambda_{i}^{\prime} may invalidate our theoretical bound on the number of flow computations required, but it makes the code much faster in practice.

  • â€¢

    In SingleBlockDistribution (lines 27â€“32), we do not always build Pğ‘ƒP because Pğ‘ƒP may be quite large for some blocks with a small number of right vertices (where râ‰ªlmuch-less-thanğ‘Ÿğ‘™r\ll l), due to the fictitious edges added. Rather, we first attempt to find lğ‘™l disjoint matchings of size rğ‘Ÿr in arbitrary order without including fictitious vertices/edges. This often succeeds and, when it does, gives a correct coloring. When this fails, we build Pğ‘ƒP and proceed to find the coloring as described.

  • â€¢

    In SingleBlockDistribution (line 32), we do not use Goel et alâ€™s edge coloring algorithm on Pğ‘ƒP. Rather, we find lğ‘™l matchings of size lğ‘™l one by one. This simplifies the implementation, but may impact performance and the runtime bound.

8.1 Fair decompositions: characteristics

TableÂ 3 shows the number of blocks kğ‘˜k in the fair decomposition (for informative purposes), the number of distinct edges e1subscriptğ‘’1e_{1} used in a maxmin-fair distribution Fğ¹F, the number of matchings Mğ‘€M in the support of Fğ¹F, and the time to compute the decomposition. As we anticipated in Section 7 the number of matchings needed for a fair distribution (Mğ‘€M) is in practice much smaller than |L|ğ¿|L|. Another observation is that e1subscriptğ‘’1e_{1} exceeds |L|ğ¿|L| only slightly. This is a measure of the storage needed to publish a summary containing the fair decomposition, the satisfaction probabilities, and the probability of each edge being used in the matching, which can be verified independently. (Publishing an explicit list of Mğ‘€M matchings of size ÏğœŒ\rho explicitly would take much more space as many of these matchings share many edges.)

8.2 Running time

In TableÂ 4 we present runtimes of all four methods for the datasets considered. Dashes indicate times above one hour. We report user times; the real times are within 2%percent22\% of these in all cases except forÂ OG, where the memory needs for graph and data structures exceeded the RAM available (16Gb), causing excessive disk swapping.

As MF has two clearly differentiated parts, we analyze two different runtimes:

  • â€¢

    Time to compute the satisfaction probabilities of each user, and the probability of using each edge in the maxmin-fair distribution (step 1, finding the fair decomposition), reported in column MF1subscriptMF1\textsf{MF}_{1};

  • â€¢

    Total time, including all of the above plus the time to find an edge coloring for each block and the list of matchings for each block (step 2), reported in column MF. (The time to draw a matching given this list, step 3, is negligible.)

No clear pattern emerges as to which of these two phases is faster in practice. As can be observed, in some instances (Vui, Cti, B, Di, de, LG, OG) the time is dominated by the first phase, wheres in others (AM, M3 and WT) the total time is much larger than the time for phase 1 only; in the latter cases the exact requirement of maxmin-fairness forces the algorithm to need a large number of matchings for some blocks, increasing the time for step 2. It seems likely that a more relaxed requirement of approximate fairness could lead to vast improvements in the runtime of step 2.

Similarly, for PS we differentiate between the time to compute the probability of each edge being used (column PS1subscriptPS1\textsf{PS}_{1}), and the total time including the former plus the time to find a distribution of matchings which agrees with those probabilities. However, this last step is much slower in the case of PS because in this case we need to use the full Birkhoff-von Neumann decomposition, instead of exploiting the degree regularity conditions of the blocks to find edge colorings as we do for MF. Because existing implementations of the Birkhoff-von Neumann decomposition do not scale even for the smaller graphs tested, we decided to omit the second phase of PS (which is not required to analyze its fairness properties).

As is to be expected, the unfair algorithmÂ UF is the fastest. As for the others, the only one which can be run to completion within one hour in all datasets is ours (MF). Its runtime is usually a handful of seconds except for the very large graphs, where it is in the order of minutes (37 minutes at most, attained for the graph WT). We can see that PS is the most computationally expensive, as many iterations of its main loop are required to reach convergence, and each iteration takes linear time. Finally, the runtime of RP is generally comparable to that of MF on small and medium-size graphs, outperforming it on many of the smaller graphs, but RP becomes slower for larger graphs; despite the additional complexity of MF, the priority mechanism of RP precludes the use of the push-relabel max-flow algorithms, and also limits the number of simultaneous augmenting paths which can be found during a single graph search in augmenting-path algorithms. Notice that these are runtimes for a single run; if the satisfaction probabilities need to be computed then it becomes necessary to run RP a large number of times, slowing it down considerably. (This is not the case for MF or PS.)

8.3 Satisfaction probability comparison

Next we analyze the satisfaction probabilities produced by maxmin-fair matchings (MF) and compare with the probabilistic serial and random-priority mechanisms. Note that the exact determination of the satisfaction probabilities of RP is computationally infeasible. To approximate them, we run RP a total of T=1000ğ‘‡1000T=1000 times with independent uniformly random permutations. (Note, however, that this does not give a good estimate of probabilities below 1/T1ğ‘‡1/T.)

For this comparison we focus on the smaller graphs, due to the limited scalability of PS (which needs a large number of iterations in its main loop, each taking linear time) and RP (which needs to be run Tğ‘‡T times to approximate the satisfaction probabilities).

Finally, tableÂ 5 reports the distribution of satisfaction probabilities: minimum value (Î»minsubscriptğœ†min\lambda_{\text{min}}), quantiles, percentage of users with satisfaction 1 (pâ€‹eâ€‹râ€‹1ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿ1per1), and Nash welfare (N0subscriptğ‘0N_{0}), the geometric mean of utilities (satisfaction probabilities in our setting). Nash welfare is a standard measure of fairness when allocating divisible resourcesÂ nash_unreasonable . As inÂ gen_nash , we also study the generalization of Nash welfare using power means (for a parameter pâˆˆâ„ğ‘â„p\in\mathbb{R}):

When p=1ğ‘1p=1, Npâ€‹(D)subscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ·N_{p}(D) is the mean satisfaction probability, which equals Ï/|L|ğœŒğ¿\rho/|L| for any Pareto-efficient mechanism. Taking the limit inÂ (5) as pâ†’0â†’ğ‘0p\to 0 one obtainsÂ (4)Â ineq_book , justifying the notation N0subscriptğ‘0N_{0} for (standard) Nash welfare. Taking the limit as pâ†’âˆ’âˆâ†’ğ‘p\to-\infty yields minuâˆˆğ’°â¡Dâ€‹[u]subscriptğ‘¢ğ’°ğ·delimited-[]ğ‘¢\min_{u\in{\mathcal{U}}}{D}[{u}], which by definition is maximized by MF.

TableÂ 6 shows these metrics for the three mechanisms tested, on those graphs where PS terminated in 8 hours. Notice that N1â€‹(MF)=N1â€‹(RP)>N1â€‹(PS)subscriptğ‘1MFsubscriptğ‘1RPsubscriptğ‘1PSN_{1}(\textsf{MF})=N_{1}(\textsf{RP})>N_{1}(\textsf{PS}), confirming that MF and RP are Pareto-efficient but PS is not. The generalized welfares for p<1ğ‘1p<1 are computed exactly for MF and PS, but estimated from the empirical probabilities after Tğ‘‡T samples for RP. (For p=0ğ‘0p=0 we replace each empirical probability qğ‘q by maxâ¡(q,1/T)ğ‘1ğ‘‡\max(q,1/T) so that the estimate is non-zero.) MF comes out on top for all (generalized) Nash welfares in all instances, in accordance with a result ofÂ dichotomous . Interestingly, N0â€‹(RP)subscriptğ‘0RPN_{0}(\textsf{RP}) is typically within 1% of N0â€‹(MF)subscriptğ‘0MFN_{0}(\textsf{MF}) (as both solutions result in a large proportion of users with high satisfaction), but for smaller pğ‘p the gap can widen to as much as 22%percent2222\% for p=âˆ’5ğ‘5p=-5, in accordance with the fact that MF was designed to provide better guarantees to low-satisfaction users.

TableÂ 7 shows the expected fraction of satisfied users among the bottom t%percentğ‘¡t\% using each method, for t=1,5,10ğ‘¡1510t=1,5,10, and 202020. Again, our method always gives the highest values, the gap with the second best being as high as 50% in some instances where t=1ğ‘¡1t=1.

TableÂ 8 reports the variance of the logarithms of satisfaction probabilities over uniformly random users, as a measure of inequality. (Taking logs penalizes wildly varying ratios of satisfaction probabilities.) We see that MF, which minimizes social inequality in the sense of Def.Â 5, also tends to minimize this quantity in all datasets tested.

9 Related work

To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to study computationally efficient randomized maxmin-fair matching algorithms, and to offer a general definition of fairness for general search problems.

The work of Bogomolnaia and MoulineÂ dichotomous on random matching under dichotomous preferences is closely related to ours: they define an egalitarian solution and show that it is envy-free, strategy-proof and group-strategy-proof with respect the set of right or left vertices. As the authors note, they do not provide an axiomatic characterization of their solution; rather, their definition of egalitarian is expressed in terms of a specific algorithm and is thus not easily generalizable to other search problems. By contrast, our definition of distributional maxmin-fairness applies to any search problem with non-unique solutions and, in the special case of bipartite matchings, is equivalent to the egalitarian solution. InÂ dichotomous two simple algorithms are proposed to find egalitarian matchings, both of them running in exponential time; our work yields a practical polynomial-time algorithm for the problem. We found no efficient algorithms or practical implementations of the egalitarian mechanism prior to our work.

Building onÂ dichotomous , Roth et alÂ kidney propose an egalitarian mechanism for the exchange of donor kidneys for transplant. McElfresh and DickersonÂ balancing_kidney propose a tradeoff between fairness and a utilitarian objective function in kidney exchange programs. Kamada and KojimaÂ matching_econ study randomized matching mechanisms for the design of matching markets under distributional constraints; their setup contains full bipartite graphs equipped with complete and strict preference relationships. Teo and SethuramanÂ geometry_matchings prove the existence of a â€œmedianâ€ deterministic solution to the stable matching problem which is fair to everyone, but finding a polynomial-time algorithm remains an open problem. ChengÂ generalized_median presents a technique to approximate the median stable matching.

In the area of resource allocation problems, several works investigate the equitable distribution of divisible resources in networks. The work of Ichimori et alÂ optimal_sharing considers a minmax-style optimization function, whereas Katoh et alÂ equipollent considers allocation problems so that the maximum of profit differences is minimized; none of these consider distributions of several solutions. Bansal et alÂ santa_claus give approximation algorithms for the Santa Claus problem, where a number of indivisible presents are to be distributed among kids who have different values for different presents, and the goal is to maximize the minimum happiness of a kid. Bertsimas et alÂ price_fairness introduce the price of fairness in resource allocation problems. A substantial amount of work has also been devoted to cake-cutting algorithms and their strategic and incentive properties: see Â fair_division_survey ; better_cake ; cake_soda and the references therein.

Several authors have studied lexicographically optimal flows in networks (which could be used in place of Step 1 of our algorithms): MeggidoÂ megiddo designed an algorithm with running time Oâ€‹(n5)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›5O(n^{5}), whereas BrownÂ sharing proposed a polynomial-time algorithm requiring nğ‘›n max flow computations. On the other hand, the parametric flow algorithm of Gallo et alÂ parametric_flow can be used to find fair decompositions with a single max flow, but is not compatible with the max flow algorithm of GoldbergÂ flow_unit . None of these methods can be used to match the runtime of our algorithm to find fair decompositions.

The bulk of the research in the area of algorithmic bias and fairness has mainly focused on avoiding discrimination against a sensitive attribute (i.e., a protected social group) in supervised machine learningÂ fairness_awareness ; FeldmanFMSV15 ; Corbett-DaviesP17 . Most of this literature focuses on statistical parity, or group-level fairness, i.e., the difference in having a positive outcome for a random individual drawn from two different subpopulations (e.g., men and women). Feldman et al.Â FeldmanFMSV15 propose to repair attributes so as to maintain per-attribute within-group ordering while enforcing statistical parity, so that a single decision threshold applied to the transformed attributes would result in equal success rate among the two different groups. Corbett-Davies et al.Â Corbett-DaviesP17 reformulate algorithmic fairness as constrained optimization in the context of criminal justice: the objective is to maximize public safety while satisfying formal fairness constraints designed to reduce disparities. Dwork et al.Â fairness_awareness provide examples showing that statistical parity alone is not sufficient for fairness, and study a randomized solution for classifiers to guarantee that â€œsimilar individuals are treated similarlyâ€ in an expected sense. The idea that more qualified individuals should be chosen preferentially is present in the work of Joseph et al.Â fairness_bandits , who study fairness in multi-armed bandit problems. Pedreschi et al.Â PedreschiRT08 introduced the related data mining problem of discovering discrimination practices in a given dataset containing past decisions; if such a dataset is used as training set for a machine learning model, the bias detected can be fixed before the learning phaseÂ KamiranC11 ; ZliobaiteKC11 . Heidari et alÂ moral show that many existing definitions of algorithmic fairness, such as predictive value parity and equality of odds can be viewed as instantiations of economic models of equality of opportunity. Heidari et alÂ ignorance study a welfare-based measure of fairness for risk-averse individuals, and derive an efficient mechanism for bounding individual-level inequality.

Finally, maxmin-fairness (in a non-distributional sense) as an objective is used for flow control in networksÂ maxmin_allocation ; data_networks . In the context of non-discrimination, the concept dates back at least to Rawlsâ€™s theory of justiceÂ theory_justice , where a â€œdifference principleâ€ is advocated whereby social and financial inequalities are required to be to the advantage of the worst-off. In Rawlsâ€™s distributive justice, social measures should be designed so as to bring the greatest benefit to the least-advantaged members of society, in order to maximize their prospects.

10 Conclusions

In this paper we study the problem of algorithmic fairness towards the elements that may or not be included in a solution of a matching problem. This is particularly (but not exclusively) important when these elements are humans. Towards this goal, we propose the distributional maxmin fairness for randomized algorithms. A series of theoretical results characterize maxmin-fair distributions and pave the road to our practical contribution: an exact polynomial-time algorithm for maxmin-fair bipartite matching, which scales to graphs with millions of vertices and hundreds of millions of edges. We also discussed methods for the transparent and accountable real-world deployment of our framework.

Regarding future work, it would be interesting to consider notions of approximate fairness intended to deal with optimization problems, where solutions may have different business value, possibly unrelated to satisfaction probabilities. The goal could be to reach a compromise between fairness and expected business value. It would be desirable to be able to find approximately maxmin-fair distributions more quickly than exact maxmin-fair distributions; we leave this as an open problem. Another interesting question is whether our methods can be extended to handle online matching/streaming settings and/or graphs which do not fit into main memory. Finally, future work may consider other notions of fairness for randomized algorithms for people search, people ranking and other learning problems.

Theorem A.1.

For matroid problems, a distribution Fğ¹F is minmax-Pareto if and only if Fğ¹F is Pareto-efficient and Fâ†“âª¯Dâ†“{F\downarrow\,}\preceq{D\downarrow\,} for all Pareto-efficient distributionsÂ Dğ·D.

Proof.

First observe that, for matroids, a distribution is Pareto-efficient if and only if it is supported over bases. For any distribution Dğ·D of bases over a matroid Mğ‘€M with ground set Lğ¿L, consider the distribution Dâˆ—superscriptğ·D^{*} of (Lâˆ–Xâˆ£Xâˆ¼D)similar-toğ¿conditionalğ‘‹ğ‘‹ğ·(L\setminus X\mid X\sim D) of bases over the dual matroid Mâˆ—superscriptğ‘€M^{*}. Then we have Dâ€‹[u]+Dâˆ—â€‹[u]=1ğ·delimited-[]ğ‘¢superscriptğ·delimited-[]ğ‘¢1{D}[{u}]+{D^{*}}[{u}]=1 for all uâˆˆLğ‘¢ğ¿u\in L, so clearly Fğ¹F is minmax-Pareto if and only if Fâˆ—superscriptğ¹F^{*} is maxmin-fair, which (by TheoremÂ 3.1) occurs if and only if Fâˆ—superscriptğ¹F^{*} is lexicographically largest for Mâˆ—superscriptğ‘€M^{*}, which in turn is equivalent to Fğ¹F being lexicographically smallest among distributions of bases of Mğ‘€M, as we wished to show. âˆ

Our next result asserts that the only obstruction to achieving high satisfaction probability for every user is the existence of a set of users with small rank-to-size ratio. Finding these obstruction sets will enable us to devise a divide and conquer strategy to obtain fair distributions. For instance, in ExampleÂ 1 the obstruction set is given by the set of users {a0,a2,a3}subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘3\{a_{0},a_{2},a_{3}\}, which force the maximum satisfaction probability to be no larger than 2323\frac{2}{3}.

Proof of TheoremÂ 3.2.

It suffices to prove the equivalence (1) â‡”â‡”\Leftrightarrow (2). Inded, if it holds, then a maxmin-fair distribution simultaneously maximizes the minimum satisfaction probability and minimizes the maximum satisfaction probability (among Pareto-efficient distributions), hence it also minimizes the largest difference between two satisfaction probabilities. An easy inductive argument (omitted) shows that the equivalence (1) â‡”â‡”\Leftrightarrow (3) then follows.
